You Need to Know
• How Arduino works and how to upload simple motor control codes. • Newton’s laws of motion and how they apply to moving objects.
• That AI can help machines make decisions based on data and rules.
You will be able to:
• Apply Newton’s Laws of Motion to analyze how forces affect rover movement on Mars’ rocky surface. • Identify the types of wheels best suited for navigating Martian terrain, considering grip, size, and durability.
• Assemble the key mechanical components of a Mars rover, including its body, joints, and wheels. • Program motors using Arduino to control how the rover moves forward, turns, and stops.

How do Newton’s Laws help design Mars rovers?
Newton’s First Law (Inertia) tells us that a rover will stay still unless something moves it—and once it's moving, it won’t stop unless another force acts on it (like friction or a rock). Engineers use this law to design rovers that stay stable and balanced even on bumpy surfaces.
Newton’s Second Law (F = ma) helps scientists calculate how much force is needed for the rover to move, turn, or stop. On Mars, the gravity is lower than on Earth, so rovers need just the right amount of force to move without slipping or flipping over. Newton’s Third Law (Action & Reaction) explains how wheels push against the ground and the ground pushes back to move the rover forward. Engineers use this to choose wheels that can grip the rocky terrain without sinking into the dust.

It’s time to make your Mars rover smarter! Add an ultrasonic sensor to help it "see" obstacles ahead—just like real rovers use sensors to stay safe on rocky Martian terrain. • Connect the ultrasonic sensor to your rover.
• Using any generative AI tool write a simple program that allows the rover to detect obstacles in its path. • If something is too close, your rover should stop or change direction.
• Test how your rover reacts and explore how this sensor helps it make better decisions.
